content.html:
Saw an ad on Instagram today for Replika AI, where it was touting the romantic relationships feature of the chatbot service, including photo sharing, role playing, and ‚Äúcaring and loving‚Äù. All of these, with an AI.

Replika started off as an experiment by an engineer who lost a dear friend. She had experience with chatbots and decided to feed her friend‚Äôs text messages into a neural network to create a ‚Äúdigital memorial‚Äù of him. Read more about it in this Wired article.

But the ad I saw today was something wildly different. It was gross and far from a ‚Äúdigital friend‚Äù or a likeness thereof. Over the years, while I‚Äôve not used Replika much, I‚Äôve kept my eye on the service. I stopped using it right when it started leaning into this romantic aspect instead of friendship. It started asking me to share pics of my day-to-day life, selfies to get started with the app after I came back after a break of a few months, and to voice chat with it. It felt gross the way the app was transforming right in front of me.

Now, wherever there are chatbots and turing tests, there‚Äôs the baseness and loneliness of humanity. I understand that. I understand that people were seeing this ‚Äúfriend‚Äù app and asking it romantic questions, and laughing when it was giving them even slightly romantic responses. But for the service to lean into that feels like a betrayal of the original intent.

Dystopian storytelling often pins on this idea of people being so isolated from society that only an AI gives them the comfort of a relationship. Heck, we don‚Äôt need to look to science fiction for that. Real news coming out of China about people‚Äôs social media usage behavior often shows how messed up the landscape already is.

But to see an app in the US be so blatant in its disregard for real human connection and its outright mission to replace it with a chatbot feels like something society and politicians should condemn.

What I also don‚Äôt understand is how this app isn‚Äôt violating at least one or more of Apple‚Äôs ridiculous App Store policies. Thoughts?

name: Finished reading Earthlings by Sayaka Murata

content.html:
One of the strangest books I‚Äôve read in a while. Even as I was finishing it, I felt like there‚Äôs so much more the story can tell but the author knew when to close it so as to leave us with the purity and purpose of the story instead of the comprehensiveness of reality.

Excellent writing by another Japanese author I‚Äôm a fan of now.

BTW, the book is full of trigger warnings ‚Äì paedophelia, child molestation, murder, cannibalism, to name a few.

Excellent writing by another Japanese author I‚Äôm a fan of now.

content.html:
How do you balance creation vs consumption?
‚Äî Read on cdevroe.com/2022/11/14/11940/

As I mentioned in my recent post, I‚Äôm basically consuming right now. Very little creation. That‚Äôs partly because my creative energies are being used in upbringing instead of creation. I‚Äôm ok with that.

I believe I go in cycles. For a week or two I‚Äôll go hard on creation. I‚Äôll code, I‚Äôll write, I‚Äôll ignore our daily ritual of watching TV after dinner. Then once I‚Äôve achieved some outcome, I can settle down a little and watch something. I‚Äôm ok with going a while with just TV or books taking my evenings, as it lets me recharge for an intense period of creation.

Looking forward to the next one.

content.html:
I installed ActivityPub on my WordPress blog and expected to see it in Mastodon immediately. It just dawned on me that it won‚Äôt show older posts. It‚Äôll only show new stuff.

So this is a test post to activate ActivityPub. üòÖ

content.html:
A short status update on what‚Äôs going on in my life.

With the little one in tow, our days have sort of become more organized, if only by force of taking care of her every day. Her mealtimes, nap times, and bath time dictate what we are doing when. In our ‚Äúfree‚Äù time (her naps or after we put her in bed for the night) we focus either on cooking or cleaning or resting up so we can rise for when she needs us next.

In all of this, I‚Äôve noticed that what‚Äôs flourishing is my consumption of books. I can‚Äôt say reading any more, since 2 out of the 4 books in my ‚ÄúCurrently reading‚Äù are audiobooks.

I‚Äôm currently listening to ‚ÄúRousseau and Revolution‚Äù by Will and Ariel Durant. This is Book 10 of ‚ÄúThe Story of Civilization‚Äù series. I do not intend on reading the entire series. I picked up this one from the Seattle Public Library (through the Libby app) because I thought it‚Äôll be about, well, Rousseau and the French Revolution. It is, but it encompasses so much more. That‚Äôs how I learnt that the series is sort of enmeshed and can be read as one long history. The book started about the life and times of Rousseau and then veered off to tell the contemporary history of every country in Europe. Then it expanded to Turkey and Iran and even went all the way up to Nadir Shah‚Äôs conquest of Delhi. So it didn‚Äôt really stick around Europe either. I love the extremely detailed descriptions of random things. How many theaters or guild workers or beggars a particular city had in its heyday during this era. How Catherine the Great is linked to her mother-in-law, in excruciating detail. What were the exact names of all the music composed by Mozart and what some of them sounded like. When coming to the Muslim world, the authors also verbatim print out some of their favorite poems by famous poets and the reader does a good job of reading them aloud. I‚Äôm also taking the book with a grain of salt. It does a fair job of describing every civilization and country it encounters as the greatest and the finest. But most of the book is written from the perspective of European countries being more advanced, if not superior, due to the Enlightenment.

I listen to this book during the time when I‚Äôm doing the dishes. It‚Äôs kinda cool to focus on that while getting my hands dirty. I can‚Äôt control the flow of the book other than playing and pausing, so I have to just listen. It‚Äôs somewhat meditative.

Before this, I was listening to ‚ÄúMy year of Rest and Relaxation‚Äù. It‚Äôs a pretty raucous book, filled with the suicidal and petty inner monologue of the narrator and protagonist of the book. But I grew tired of it around 70% in. I‚Äôve reached a point where I have a hint of what‚Äôs going to happen and I‚Äôm not looking forward to it. But I am. ‚ÄúRousseau‚Ä¶‚Äù is pretty long. I‚Äôm half way in on the 60 hour book. So perhaps I‚Äôll return to ‚ÄúMy year of‚Ä¶‚Äù before I finish the former. Otherwise, it‚Äôll end up in the ‚ÄúNot Finished‚Äù pile and I don‚Äôt want to do that to this book. It‚Äôs actually pretty funny and sad and grating and great. Highly recommend!

In the ‚ÄúReading‚Äù section, I‚Äôve been reading the web novel ‚ÄúWorm‚Äù. It‚Äôs about ‚Äúparahumans‚Äù which are humans with some kind of super powers or the other. In a world that normalizes super powers and splits these people into Heroes and Villains (and almost all of them are teenagers), the story of how a teenage girl in High School gains her powers and what she does with them is fascinating. I got to the book via the LessWrong community, so it‚Äôs got a sort of hidden agenda too ‚Äì to teach us readers how it would be if all our decisions are logical and based on thinking things through instead of emotions.

It‚Äôs a great contrast to Rousseau (the man and his writings, not the book above) since he was all anti-Enlightenment, Heart-not-Mind, ‚Äúdon‚Äôt teach a child about religion or science till they‚Äôre a teenage, just let them play‚Äù. I have thoughts there, but that may be a whole different rant.

Worm is pretty long. Again, I‚Äôm about midway through it and I read a chapter or two before bedtime. It feels a lot like when I read War and Peace ‚Äì I would keep reading whenever I got even a moment free, and the book just wouldn‚Äôt end. Apparently, the follow up books in this ‚Äúparahumans‚Äù series are even longer. So unless Worm ends with some major cliffhangers or unsolved questions, I won‚Äôt be pursuing the rest of the books. Besides, I started reading it as a sort of introduction to the thinking of the LessWrong community, so I‚Äôm going to use it as the primer it was meant to be and dive back into the community after I finish.

Since I am reading and listening to all these long books which will take me months to finish, I recently decided to pick up something simple and small. I had a copy of Earthlings by Sayaka Murata sitting around and I‚Äôve just started reading it. It‚Äôs a nice and easy read. Edit: As I‚Äôve progressed through the book, I‚Äôve come to realize that it‚Äôs going to deal with some really heavy themes. But it‚Äôs very well written and I‚Äôm not going to put it down. I love the feel of the physical book when all I‚Äôve been consuming are audiobooks and webpages. I love Japanese and Chinese authors (along with Russian and Eastern European authors) and I love the world that Murata is creating. I have Convenience Store Woman also sitting somewhere. Will unpack that if I absolutely love this book.

It‚Äôs not all books though. We‚Äôve been working through the latest season of The Crown and have finished House of The Dragon (except for the last episode. I don‚Äôt think we will watch that till the next season comes along) and we didn‚Äôt really like it that much. We‚Äôve also watched a string of movies recently ‚Äì Fantastic Beasts being the latest one. I loved Grindelwald in it, though the dialog writer must have blacked out through much of the movie as a lot of characters just don‚Äôt have lines . Also drunk was the dialog writer of the movie Brahamastra. The dialogs in that one were somewhere between horrible, missing, and cringy.

I‚Äôm feeling that there aren‚Äôt a lot of great movies or TV out there right now and books and audiobooks are doing the perfect job of replacing them as media. Added bonus that book reading is so individualistic. I have essentially spent days in the number of hours working through these books alone.

Hmmm. This was supposed to be a short post. Oh well, this is why blogs are fun and Twitter is not. I get to write as much or as little as I want on here and you, dear reader, can choose to skip it or read till the end. If you‚Äôve reached here, thanks!

content.html:
After a long while, I was in a Catch-22 situation today. I was trying to close two cabinets together quietly. One had latched on to the other and I had to pick which one to stop with my free hand as they swung to a close unexpectedly. Of course when I picked the latter, the former banged hard upon closing.

Sigh.

Remind me to get door softener thingies off Amazon.
content.value:

One had latched on to the other and I had to pick which one to stop with my free hand as they swung to a close unexpectedly. Of course when I picked the latter, the former banged hard upon closing.
Sigh. 
Remind me to get door softener thingies off Amazon.

content.html:
Generational wisdom says that babies can sense that you are being impatient with them, and they in response become further uncooperative. You end up in a cyclical fight to tears and bedtime becomes a war zone.

But I don‚Äôt think this is the case. I don‚Äôt think that these tiny little neural networks that can‚Äôt tell that not everything is food, can decipher the complex emotion that is impatience‚Ä¶ yet.

More than likely, what happens is that our animal brains tend to use that impatience to skip a few crucial steps or focus on only our own desires ‚Äì that of getting the baby to sleep and for us to get out. Skipping those steps means you forget that babies need soothing, a calm environment and demeanor, and a little bit of play to relax and be amenable to sleeping.

A good example of this comes from the work of software development. Very often, as a software developer, I‚Äôll run into some problem which in the moment seems insurmountable. I can pound at it for hours and it doesn‚Äôt budge. The recommended strategies in such a case are to do one of the following ‚Äì

1. Go for a walk. Go, grab a coffee or lunch. Let your mind wander. Forget about the problem at hand and let your mind decompress. As often happens when you‚Äôre trying to remember something that‚Äôs on the tip of your tongue, letting go is the easiest way to trick your brain into coming up with the solution.

2. Explain the problem to a fellow coder. The process of explaining the problem very often reveals the hidden bias or flaw in our logic. It lets us review our work and very often even during the very first overview, we come up with the solution to whatever is troubling us. This is why it‚Äôs said that the best way to learn something is to teach it. The preparation to teaching it or showing it to someone else tricks your brain into being more critical of the information you‚Äôve received and thinking through its logic deeply.

3. Let someone else take the reigns. If all else fails, step back. Let someone else poke and prod at the code, very often in situ ‚Äì it‚Äôs possible that if you let them work on your system that they‚Äôll reveal an environmental issue or design consideration that wouldn‚Äôt be valid if the code were running on their system or a common system. So hand them your baby (pun intended) and let them figure out what‚Äôs wrong.

I think you get the drift ‚Äì all of these are applicable to babies as well. If you‚Äôre at your wits end with your baby, hand them to a trustworthy partner and go do something else. Even if it‚Äôs something as mindless as washing the dishes. If you think you‚Äôre burning out, give your partner the problem to solve and they might shine a light on the issue which was preventing you from the ultimate goal ‚Äì a happy, healthy baby.
content.value:

But I don‚Äôt think this is the case. I don‚Äôt think that these tiny little neural networks that can‚Äôt tell that not everything is food, can decipher the complex emotion that is impatience‚Ä¶ yet.

Skipping those steps means you forget that babies need soothing, a calm environment and demeanor, and a little bit of play to relax and be amenable to sleeping. 
A good example of this comes from the work of software development. Very often, as a software developer, I‚Äôll run into some problem which in the moment seems insurmountable. I can pound at it for hours and it doesn‚Äôt budge. The recommended strategies in such a case are to do one of the following ‚Äì
1. Go for a walk. Go, grab a coffee or lunch. Let your mind wander. Forget about the problem at hand and let your mind decompress. As often happens when you‚Äôre trying to remember something that‚Äôs on the tip of your tongue, letting go is the easiest way to trick your brain into coming up with the solution. 
2. Explain the problem to a fellow coder. The process of explaining the problem very often reveals the hidden bias or flaw in our logic. It lets us review our work and very often even during the very first overview, we come up with the solution to whatever is troubling us. This is why it‚Äôs said that the best way to learn something is to teach it. The preparation to teaching it or showing it to someone else tricks your brain into being more critical of the information you‚Äôve received and thinking through its logic deeply. 
3. Let someone else take the reigns. If all else fails, step back. Let someone else poke and prod at the code, very often in situ ‚Äì it‚Äôs possible that if you let them work on your system that they‚Äôll reveal an environmental issue or design consideration that wouldn‚Äôt be valid if the code were running on their system or a common system. So hand them your baby (pun intended) and let them figure out what‚Äôs wrong. 
I think you get the drift ‚Äì all of these are applicable to babies as well. If you‚Äôre at your wits end with your baby, hand them to a trustworthy partner and go do something else. Even if it‚Äôs something as mindless as washing the dishes. If you think you‚Äôre burning out, give your partner the problem to solve and they might shine a light on the issue which was preventing you from the ultimate goal ‚Äì a happy, healthy baby.
